Description: Petition to the Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal by residents of Beulah re Daniel JONES, Croesnwydd, Beulah. Page 1 of 2

Transcription: To the members of the Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal. Gentlemen:- We, the undersigned, being residents of Beulah do hereby humbly beg to petition you for the dismissal of the appeal of the military representative against the decision of the local tribunal re the case of Mr Daniel JONES, Croesnwydd. We base our reasons for petitioning on the following grounds: 1. Two of his brothers are already in the army. 2. His mother's health is in such a bad state at present that we consider it impossible for him to leave her now. He does all the housework for her, and she has nobody upon whom she can rely but him. 3. Many of us being small holders, we will greatly miss the help of JONES during the forth coming harvest. The neighbouring farmer's being short of hands this year, we cannot expect any help from them as we used to, and we consider that it is not too much for us as small holders to have one person at least who can render us occasional help that is if his mother's health at the time will be in such a state as to be able to spare him from the house for a few hours now and again. Name and address of Petitioner Employment Eliza & Letitia EVANS, Blainllebu Small Holder Griffith DAVIES, Frongoch Small Holder Hannah JONES, Penlanbach Small Farmer D G JAMES, Maesygelli Farmer O D DAVIES, Beulah Minister of the Capel & Small Holder David JONES, Ffosyrhendy Farmer D MORRIS, Plasnewydd Small Farmer John D JONES, Plasnewyyd Master Mariner

Transcription: National School Aberystwyth October 18th 1916 To: Evan Evans Esq Solicitor Aberystwyth Dear Sir RE Daniel Jones 2 Church Street, Llandyssul I feel deeply grateful for this opportunity and priviledge to express a few words, which concern the case of Daniel Jones, and which you will kindly place for consideration before the County Tribunal. I shall endeavour to put the facts concisely in the following statements:- 1. My father, who is 91 years of age, requires asistance in undressing and dressing. In the night he gets periodical attacks, which necessitate urgent attention, because he experiences a difficulty in breathing. 2. My stepmother died last May, so now the only one to give loving attention and thoughtful care is my brother, whose work is a tailor at home, so father gets his direct attention and supervision constantly. 3. My brother's wife does not live with him. Her health too is liable to nervous break-downs, and for obvious reasons she is not available and willing to undertake domestic duties. 4. Father's age creates a natural difficulty in finding suitable lodgings, because it would be impossible to get anyone to give the essential attention and again it would be practically impossible to get anyone to undertake the responsibility at home without

My father has one son and six grandsons already serving in the army, and I feel it would be a terrible burden for an old man at his age to break up a home now. 7. I understand that my brother is medically unfit owing to heart trouble, as this additional fact emphasizes a favourable decision in this case I should like to express my most earnest appeal to the Tribunal to give a sympathetic consideration to this case, which, I can assure you , is most deserving, and I have every confidence that you will not consider this letter as obtrusive, but rather as an expression of filial attachment to a father whose last few years are an object of considerable anxiety to me, if existing conditions of living will be changed. Description: Letter from WILLIAMS & Son, 21 Belle Vue Street, Swansea in support of their employee Mr E ESAU, 4 Marble Terrace.

Transcription: 2 October 1916 Dear Sirs We shall be glad if you will read the following letter to your committee with reference to our local agent Mr E ESAU, 4 Marble Terrace. We should like your committee to consider his case very seriously in as much as his wife owing to her having a young child is unable to do any of his work, as he is compelled to do some on cycle, and we are unable to get anyone to do his work. It would be rather a great hard-ship on his part, because practically speaking he has opened up the whole connection in that district, as if he should be called up, and we have to take on a substitute it is quite possible that substitute would not undertake the work unless it was guarante regular. We may also add we have the majority of our men called up and at the moment we do not know of anyone that would take on the LLANDYSSUL branch for us, however under the above circumstances and the fact that his wife is unable to carry on the branch. We trust you will give him several months exemption with leave to appeal again . Thanking you for your consideration in the

Description: Note from David Davies, Llwyneos, Llandyssul concerning his domestic circumstances

Transcription: I appeal for an exemption on the ground of "Serious Domestic Hardship". I am nearly 34 years of age and am the only son of the family. I have one sister who is married with 4 children, the eldest of which is only 10 yrs of age. She is suffering from an ulcerated leg for the last 10 yrs & is quite incapable of giving me any assistance, as is shown by the Medical Certificate herewith. My father is nearly 75 yrs of age and is suffering from Chronic Bronchitis and a serious rupture as per Certificate and he is quite unable to do any work of any kind or hardly move about. My mother is 70 yrs of age and is of very weak mind and is being medically attended to, as per Medical Certificate herewith. She was a few years ago an inmate of the Carmarthen Mental Hospital owing to her mind being deranged through being disapointed [sic]. When we had her home we had to undertake to be watchful about her, as she is very apt to do harm herself. We have to be very tender towards her and have to take care not to dissapoint [sic] her in any way as the least thing is enough to upset her. I am the only means of support of my aged Parents in keeping the home going & should I be called up it would be a very serious hardship on them, and it would be enough to derange my Mother's mind again, and owing to her advanced age the probability is she would be beyond recovery. What then would be waiting me back but a motherless home and a broken hearted old father. I'm sure if ever there was a case of "Serious Domestic hardship" that my case is a most deserving one. Trusting that you will consider my case from my standpoint and that you will grant me a Conditional exemption the same as the Local Tribunal being they knew the situation so well.

Description: Letter from David O. Jones, Schoolmaster relating to David Powell of Closygraig, Glanarthen

Transcription: Glanarthen, Henllan, Cards. March 27th 1917. To. The Chairman of "The Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal" Sir On behalf of my neighbour - Mr Dd Powell of Closygraig, Glanarthen I beg to make the following observations which may prove helpful to enable the Tribunal to decide his case. He was brought up from childhood on a farm and is consequently fully acquainted with all agricultural operations. After leaving school he was employed for many years as a farmhand at various large farms in this locality, becoming i due course "horseman" and "ploughman" and taking charge if all the ordinary machines used in farm-work. Since learning his vocation of country mason at the age of 19, he has at times left the building trade altogether and returned to his employment as farm-servant often for months together, and invariably every year during the hay and corn harvests, this being a special conditions of the tenancy of the holding which he has occupied for over 7 years. In compliance with the instructions of the Local Tribunal at their meeting when his case was dealt with he has been working full time upon local farms where his services are in constant demand owing to the great dearth of experienced far-hands.In conclusion I most strongly recommend him as a most suitable person whose services should be returned in agriculture. Yours truly, David O. Jones, (Schoolmaster)

Transcription: From: The Local Food Control Committee for the Llandyssul Rural District Council, 12 Lincoln Street, Llandyssul To: Evan EVANS, Clerk Appeal Tribunal, Aberystwyth 18 May 1918 Dear Sir The above Committee has had under consideration the question of the retention in civil life of John Emlyn JONES of Cwmcoy Stores, Cwmcoy, Newcaslte Emlyn, whose case is down for hearing at the Cardiagnshire Appeal Tribunal, to be held at Lampeter on Wednesday the 22nd instant. Mr JONES is a single man about 27 years of age, and have been placed by the Medical Board in Grade 2. He is a General and Provision Merchant carrying on business at Cwmcoy Stores aforesaid and is also Sub-Postmaster. His is the only business at Cwmcoy, a village situated about 1 1/2 miles from Newcastle Emlyn. He is registered with this Committee as a retailer of Sugar and Margarine. The number of this registered customers for sugar is 279. he serves a wide agricultural district and has no one to carry on the business if he is called up to join the army. I was directed to point out to you that this Committee was of opinion that the closing of this establishment would cause serious dislocation of business in the locality and grave inconvenience to his customers. I am also to express the hope that having regard to the above facts and to his medical category favourable consideration will be given to his case Yours faithfully James JONES Executive Officer

Description: Page 1 correspondence by A.T. Evan M.B. on behalf of G. Emlyn Jones regarding his health.

Transcription: Rock House Llandysul 20. May. 18 Dear Sir, I write in regard to can G Evilyn(?) Jones of Cwmcry(?) Shop. Who is my nephew + whom I have medically attended. He is on the list to appear before the County Tribunal on Wednesday next, - but at present is medically unfit to do so. - Twelve months ago he fractured his kneecap, was graded C.3., in Feb last he was passed grade II. - Three weeks ago I attended him and found him suffering from what I took to be Influenza a+ Bronchial Catarrh. Owing to the distance I asked Dr Lloyd of Newcastle to see him in my stead. Dr Lloyd called me in consultation on Thursday last. + to my great surprise + vexation I found complete loss of voice, cough + commencing tubercular disease of both lungs. Dr. Lloyd agreed with me in this, + we referred the case for the opinion of Dr. D.Ches(?) Lloyd. The local Tuberculosis Physician, who

Name of Tribunal: Llandysul Rural District

Recruiting Office as to my next procedure - whether to get him re-examined at Carm. or to refer him to the Central Medical Board in London. - He is at present unfit to appear before the Tribunal. and unless he improves in the next two days it would be very unwise for him to take the journey. Every effort has been made to replace these men but without success. So it is evident that we are already seriously understaffed and have experienced great difficulties. The Gomerian Press office was established over 25 years ago and up to the present moment has supplied an area covering 15 miles radium with almost the whole of the printing required. Description: Letter in support of application in answer to section 6 & 7 by William Samuel WILLIAMS, Tailor, Pontshaen.

Transcription: For section 6 & 7. My late father who died last July carried on business of Tailoring in Pontshaen for over 40 years. on leaving school at 14 years of age I became apprentice to my father and worked with him untill his death. Since his death I carried on the business myself and just now I have a young nephew of mine, a lad of 14 years of age, as apprentice. I am the only Tailor in the neighbourhood, the nearest tailor in one direction being 3 1/2 miles away, the nearest in the every other direction being 4 1/2 miles away. I do work for about 80 farms and about an equal number of cottagers. I have in stock material to the value of about £100 and my customers owe me something like £200. My late father bequeathed me the house and shop in which I live to carry on the business on condition that I bought up my young nephew and providing him with a home. clothing etc untill he is 21 years of age. Further I have to teach him in the tailoring trade free of charge. Were I called up I should have to break up my home and dispose of my business that of course would be financial ruin to me. I have being examined by the medical board and placed me in class C3 only. Re Question 7 Soon after the military service act came into force my later father appealed for me to the Llandyssul Rural Tribunal and I was granted condition exemption in Oct 1916. 3 months after my father's death the Military Representative called my case up for review again the Local Tribunal granted me conditional exemption. The Military Representative appeal against their decision and the appeal tribunal granted me 3 months and a right to appeal in February last. My appeal was again considered by the Appeal Tribunal and I was granted a further exemption of 3 months with right of appeal.

Description: Letter from James EVANS, Manchester House, Llandyssul to E EVANS, Cardiganshire County Appeal Tribunal

Transcription: Manchester House, Llandyssul 19/10/18 Dear Sir I am in receipt of your notice requesting my appearance on Friday before the County Tribunal. Since having lodged my appeal I have received from National Service Medical Board, Brecon, certificate discharging me as being permanently and totally unfit for any military duties. This was issued on the 9th of this month and signed by J B MARTIN for Minister National Service. Is it therefore necessary that I should appear. A reply at your earliest will oblige. Yours sincerely James EVANS Evan EVANS Esq

Description: Letter from Ministry of National Service, Brecon to Dr A T EVANS, Rock House, Llandyssul re appeal for David JONES, Ffoshelig, Llandyssul

Transcription: All communications to be addressed to The Secretary quoting this reference: BREC/Med/34 MINISTRY OF NATIONAL SERVICE Area Headquarters 16 Bridge St, BRECON 21/7/18 To: Dr A T EVANS, Rock House, Llandyssul Sir, DAVID JONES, Ffoshelig, Llandyssul, Cardiganshire I have made careful enquires in this case and can find no evidence in support of the man statement that he has appealed and been granted re-examination. I have scrutinised carefully the lists of those who have been granted leave to be re-examined by the appeal tribunal and cannot trace that he has made an application. If I am misinformed I shall be glad to the know the date on which the Appeal Tribunal granted him leave. If the man has made a mistake I shall be glad if he will apply to the Appeal Tribunal for leave to be re-examined by the Medical Assessors and will instruct my representative to support the application. This procedure will I believe, be satisfactory to all parties. Yours faithfully, A E CHAPMAN Asst Director of National Serv', Breconshire Area
